claim: Most middle class families have butlers.

supporting.text: Butlers are traditionally associated with wealthy or upper-class households, not middle-class families, as they require significant financial resources to employ.

attacks.text: Butlers are traditionally associated with wealthy or upper-class households, not middle-class families, as they require significant financial resources to employ.
Modern middle-class families may employ part-time or shared butlers as a cost-effective alternative to full-time domestic staff.
Part-time or shared butler services are still prohibitively expensive for most middle-class families, maintaining the financial barrier.
The definition of 'butler' has expanded to include various domestic service roles that are more affordable for middle-class budgets.
Traditional butler roles require specialized training and full-time availability, which cannot be replaced by generalized domestic help.

supporting.text: Statistical data from labor and household surveys show that domestic staff like butlers are rare in middle-class households due to cost constraints.

attacks.text: Statistical data from labor and household surveys show that domestic staff like butlers are rare in middle-class households due to cost constraints.
Some middle-class families in high-income regions or with dual high-earning parents may afford butlers, skewing the general rarity claim.
Even in high-income regions, the proportion of middle-class families hiring butlers remains statistically insignificant compared to the global middle-class population.
The definition of 'butler' may vary; part-time or shared domestic helpers could be misclassified as butlers in surveys.
Labor surveys explicitly distinguish full-time butlers from other domestic staff, minimizing classification errors.

supporting.text: Modern middle-class lifestyles typically rely on automation (e.g., appliances) or occasional hired help rather than full-time domestic staff like butlers.

attacks.text: Modern middle-class lifestyles typically rely on automation (e.g., appliances) or occasional hired help rather than full-time domestic staff like butlers.
In some high-cost-of-living cities, middle-class families may employ full-time domestic staff due to dual-income time constraints.
Even in high-cost areas, butlers remain rare for middle-class households as they prioritize childcare over traditional domestic roles.
Historical data shows middle-class families in the early 20th century often employed domestic staff, suggesting possible cultural revival.
Modern labor costs and social norms make historical domestic staffing levels economically unrealistic for middle-class budgets.

supporting.text: Cultural norms in most countries do not associate butlers with middle-class families, as this role is historically linked to aristocracy or high-income elites.

attacks.text: Cultural norms in most countries do not associate butlers with middle-class families, as this role is historically linked to aristocracy or high-income elites.
In some affluent regions, middle-class families may employ domestic staff, including butlers, due to economic prosperity and cultural shifts.
Even in affluent regions, butlers remain rare among middle-class families due to high costs and modern alternatives like automated home systems.
Historical data shows that butler employment has declined globally, further reducing its relevance to any income group today.

supporting.text: The median income of middle-class families globally is insufficient to cover the salary of a full-time butler, making this claim economically implausible.

attacks.text: The median income of middle-class families globally is insufficient to cover the salary of a full-time butler, making this claim economically implausible.
In some high-income countries, middle-class families can afford part-time or shared butler services.
Part-time or shared butler services do not meet the definition of 'having a butler' as implied by the original claim.
Historical data shows that butlers were more common in the past when labor costs were lower.
Current economic conditions and labor laws make historical comparisons irrelevant to the present claim.
